question: Will semaglutide injections be in shortage according to the FDA on April 1, 2025?
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**BCG Vaccine Shortage Ends in the United States**
A recombinant Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (rBCG) vaccine, TUBERVAC-rBCG, is now available in the United States to treat non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) patients, ending a multi-year shortage of the TICE BCG vaccine. The vaccine was approved by the FDA and will be shipped by the Serum Institute of India (SII) starting February 19, 2025. Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, Founder of ImmunityBio, said, 'With the increasing threat of supply shortages of essential medicines, the biopharmaceutical industry must innovate and secure new means of ensuring uninterrupted access to vital therapeutics.' The rBCG vaccine has demonstrated potent immunogenicity and improved safety compared to earlier BCG strains and formulations. ImmunityBio's ANKTIVA, a cytokine interleukin-15, plays a crucial role in the immune system and integrates with rBCG vaccinations.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 03:08 PM
Source:[precisionvaccinations.com](https://www.vax-before-travel.com/bcg-vaccine-shortage-ends-united-states-2025-02-19)

**ImmunityBio (IBRX): FDA Authorizes ImmunityBio to Provide Recombinant BCG (rBCG) to Urologists to Address TICE® BCG Shortage**
The U.S. FDA has authorized an expanded access program for ImmunityBio to provide a recombinant BCG (rBCG) vaccine to urologists to address the shortage of TICE BCG in the U.S. The shortage has hindered the treatment of bladder cancer patients, with 57% of urologists surveyed unable to treat patients in the last 12 months due to lack of access to TICE BCG. The rBCG vaccine, developed by the Serum Institute of India, has shown potent immunogenicity and improved safety in European bladder cancer clinical trials. Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, Founder of ImmunityBio, said, 'Our collaboration with the FDA and Serum Institute to ensure a reliable supply of this vital drug for bladder cancer patients underscores ImmunityBio’s commitment to addressing critical access issues that affect so many patients.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 02:01 PM
Source:[streetinsider.com](https://www.streetinsider.com/Corporate+News/ImmunityBio+%28IBRX%29%3A+FDA+Authorizes+ImmunityBio+to+Provide+Recombinant+BCG+%28rBCG%29+to+Urologists+to+Address+TICE%C2%AE+BCG+Shortage/24368914.html)

**Medication Shortage Persists in Kuzbass: Is It Due to Budget Cuts?**
Residents of Kuzbass continue to complain about the inability to obtain subsidized medications. Although not as widespread as in January, the problem persists. The Ministry of Health attributes the situation to the 'one-time' approach of beneficiaries in submitting prescriptions for 2024 and 2025. However, people wonder if the region's budget, which has reduced spending (e.g., by eliminating the subsidy for transportation for students), is connected to the shortage. The Ministry of Health responded that the number of people receiving subsidized medications has increased from 153,333 in 2023 to 167,580 in 2024, and 170,000 in 2025. The total cost of dispensing medications has also increased, from 4.37 billion rubles in 2024 to the same amount in 2025, despite a 2.5% increase in the number of beneficiaries and an 11% increase in medication prices. The Ministry has promised to deliver medications to patients' homes, including those with chronic illnesses, the elderly, and those living in remote areas. However, four medications are currently unavailable: clopicxol and methylprednisolone tablets, Humalog insulin, and Ionsoteryl infusion solution. Patients are advised to consult their doctors to find alternative treatments. The problem of medication shortages has been reported in many regions, with some even conducting investigations. In Kuzbass, the prosecutor's office has received complaints from citizens and has taken measures to ensure that patients receive necessary medications and are reimbursed for any costs incurred in purchasing medications themselves. ' 
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 19, 2025 03:30 AM
Source:[Аргументы и факты](https://kuzbass.aif.ru/society/ekonomyat-na-lekarstvah-v-aptekah-kuzbassa-net-chetyryoh-lgotnyh-preparatov)

**Sheinbaum Rejects Medication Shortage: 'That No Longer Occurs'**
Mexico City, February 18, 2025 - President Claudia Sheinbaum denied the existence of a shortage of medications and healthcare supplies in the country, stating, 'Eso ya no ocurre' (That no longer occurs). Sheinbaum assured that, starting from March, all medications will be guaranteed. According to her, a significant purchase was made for the next two years to resupply the shortage caused by the end of certain contracts with pharmaceutical companies in late 2024. The president mentioned that all medications will be free and not only cover basic diseases, but also more complex ones, including medical interventions. Sheinbaum emphasized that 'all insumos (medications and supplies) will be free and accessible to everyone' in the public healthcare system. The president also mentioned that three central systems in the healthcare sector will benefit from the recent purchase.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 18, 2025 04:26 PM
Source:[Quadratín CDMX](https://mexico.quadratin.com.mx/rechaza-sheinbaum-desabasto-de-medicamentos-eso-ya-no-ocurre/)

**Hims & Hers: From Viral Ad to Volatile Stock**
Hims & Hers Health's stock price has surged, reaching new 52-week and all-time highs above $60. Several factors contribute to this increase, including the company's high-profile Super Bowl advertisement and growing investor interest in telehealth, particularly in weight management. The advertisement directly addressed the growing obesity crisis in America, portraying Hims & Hers' medications as affordable and accessible solutions. However, the commercial drew criticism from senators, regulatory bodies, and pharmaceutical industry groups, who questioned the ad's potential to mislead consumers and raised concerns about patient safety. Despite the controversy, the advertisement succeeded in capturing widespread attention and likely contributed to the surge in stock value. Hims & Hers has also strategically entered the GLP-1 weight loss medication market, offering compounded versions of semaglutide due to shortages of branded medications. This move has significantly impacted their financial performance, with a 77% revenue increase and a 44% subscriber increase in Q3 2024. The company's revenue growth remains a standout metric, with a substantial 77% increase in the third quarter of 2024 compared to the same period in 2023. Hims & Hers is also showing positive trends in profitability, with a net income of $75.6 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of $51.1 million in Q3 2024. However, the company faces regulatory risks, competitive pressures, and questions about the sustainability of its current growth drivers, warranting a cautious approach.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 12:15 PM
Source:[marketbeat.com](https://www.marketbeat.com/stock-ideas/hims-and-hers-from-viral-ad-to-volatile-stock/)

**Major Market Shift in Egrifta (Tesamorelin Acetate) Industry: Resumption Of Synthetic Peptide Drug Production And Supply Management In The HIV-Related Lipodystrophy Market**
The egrifta (tesamorelin acetate) market is expected to experience significant growth, driven by the increasing incidence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infections. According to the Minnesota Department of Health, there was a 24% increase in new HIV diagnoses in 2023 compared to 2022. The market size is predicted to escalate from $XX million in 2024 to $XX million in 2025, with a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of $XX%. Theratechnologies Inc., a biopharmaceutical firm, has restarted production of EGRIFTA SV, a synthetic peptide drug, after a voluntary closure of its contract manufacturer's facility. The company is managing inventory to ensure patient needs are met until mid-January 2025 and collaborating with the FDA to avoid a supply shortage in 2025. The egrifta (tesamorelin acetate) market is segmented by clinical indication, distribution channel, and end-users, with North America being the largest region in 2024 and Asia-Pacific expected to be the fastest-growing region in the forecast period.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 06:05 AM
Source:[openPR.com - Open Public Relations Free of Charge](https://www.openpr.com/news/3872844/major-market-shift-in-egrifta-tesamorelin-acetate-industry)

**Russia Faces Shortage of High Blood Pressure Medication 'Аттенто'**
The medication 'Аттенто' used to treat high blood pressure has become scarce in Russia. According to cardiologist Krestina Bockova, the medication is convenient for patients as it contains two active ingredients, amlopidine and olmesartan medoxomil, in one tablet. The medication has been unavailable since September 2023, and even online pharmacies are unable to find it. The Russian Association of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers has stated that the medication will not be available in Russia until the end of 2025. However, cardiologist Krestina Bockova suggests that patients can replace 'Аттенто' with other medications that contain similar active ingredients, such as 'Кардосал' or 'Телмиста АМ', after consulting with their doctor.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 18, 2025 06:00 AM
Source:[74.ru](https://74.ru/text/health/2025/02/18/75119087/)

**Medicine Shortage in Colombia: A Concern for the Fight Against Tuberculosis**
The National Institute of Vigilance of Medicines and Foods (Invima) has reported a shortage of medicines in Colombia. According to Invima, the shortage is due to an increase in demand, problems in the acquisition of raw materials, and a lack of producers or laboratories that produce the medicine. The shortage affects various medicines, including Ataluren, used to treat a rare disease, and antitubercular medicines, which are essential for the treatment of tuberculosis. The Association of Infectologists of Colombia (Acin) has warned about the shortage of antitubercular medicines, which could have severe consequences for the fight against the disease. The Ministry of Health is responsible for acquiring these medicines annually to ensure their availability, but the delivery of the compound Rhze, which was scheduled for September, has been delayed until December. The shortage of medicines is a concern for the authorities and health organizations due to its impact on the treatment of tuberculosis, which remains one of the main causes of morbidity and mortality in the country, especially in vulnerable populations. According to Invima, the main causes of shortage are: increase in demand, problems in the acquisition of raw materials, and lack of producers or laboratories that produce the medicine. The Invima has also reported that the following medicines are at risk of shortage: Enalapril tablets of 5mg, Hidroxiurea (Hidroxicarbamida) capsules of 500 mg, Lamotrigina tablets of 100mg / 50mg, Midazolam injectable solution 5mg/5m, and Fentanilo patch transdermal 8.4 mg and Fenilbutirato de sodio 48.3 g granules, which have been officially discontinued in the country since January 29, 2025.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 18, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[hoydiariodelmagdalena.com.co](https://hoydiariodelmagdalena.com.co/archivos/1074547/se-agrava-la-escasez-de-medicamentos/)

**Roszdravnadzor Recommends Alternative Therapy for Patients Taking 'Atento'**
The Roszdravnadzor (Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare) in the Sverdlovsk region recommends that patients taking the medication 'Atento' find an alternative therapy with the help of a doctor. The medication, used to treat essential hypertension, has not been available in the civilian market since September 2023, according to the Roszdravnadzor's website. However, the agency notes that there are limited quantities of the medication remaining in the region and that there are many analogs available on the market. This comes after the agency previously denied reports of a shortage of medications for hypophysis pathologies, stating that over 440,000 packages of the medications 'Lanreotide', 'Octreotide', and 'Pegvisomant' are available. 'The last time the medication 'Atento' was available in the civilian market was in September 2023. As a result, according to the information posted in the system for monitoring the movement of medicinal products, there are limited quantities of the mentioned medicinal product on the territory of the Sverdlovsk region,' the agency stated on its VKontakte page.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 17, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[m24.ru](https://www.m24.ru/news/obshchestvo/17022025/771174)

**Rising Demand for GLP-1 Receptor Agonists Means an Increase in Patient Questions**
The demand for GLP-1 receptor agonists, such as semaglutide (Ozempic, Wegovy) and liraglutide (Saxenda, Victoza), has surged due to their effectiveness in weight loss and glycemic control. However, this increased demand has led to nationwide shortages, particularly for off-label use for weight management. Pharmacists are struggling to manage the distribution of these medications, and patients may face difficulties maintaining glycemic control. According to Dr. Mahapatra, semaglutide has shown positive results in clinical studies, with participants achieving an average weight loss of 15% to 17% over 68 weeks.  The shortage has raised economic and ethical concerns, with some patients facing inflated prices or resorting to secondary markets. Pharmaceutical companies are ramping up production, but it may take months or years to resolve the issue. Health care providers are encouraged to consider alternative therapies for patients affected by the shortage. Improved patient education is also vital to managing expectations and ensuring adherence to available treatments.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2025 03:21 PM
Source:[pharmacytimes.com](https://www.pharmacytimes.com/view/rising-demand-for-glp-1-receptor-agonists-means-an-increase-in-patient-questions)

**‘Check before you inject’: Novo bites back at Hims & Hers Super Bowl ad**
Novo Nordisk has released a print ad in The New York Times criticizing the safety and efficacy of compounded GLP-1s, following a controversial Super Bowl ad by Hims & Hers promoting its compounded GLP-1 offerings. The Novo ad, which reads 'Check before you inject,' questions the quality of compounded semaglutide and highlights the potential risks to patients. Novo has been fighting against compounded GLP-1s for years, launching lawsuits and pushing the FDA to prohibit them from the market. The FDA allows compounded drugs if a patient can't be treated with an FDA-approved medication or if there are shortages of branded drugs. Novo argues that compounding pharmacies 'may call it 'semaglutide,' but it's not real FDA-approved medicine, and it's not proven safe or effective.' Hims & Hers' Super Bowl ad generated 7.7 times as much engagement as the average ad, but was criticized by lawmakers for lacking side-effect disclosure and safety information.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2025 07:31 PM
Source:[prweek.com](https://www.prweek.com/article/1906355/check-inject-novo-bites-back-hims-hers-super-bowl-ad)

**FDA maintains discretion on GLP-1 compounding**
The FDA has maintained its previous statement that the tirzepatide injection shortage is resolved, but has also stated that it will not take action against pharmacies or outsourcing facilities that compound, distribute, or dispense tirzepatide injections until February 18, 2025, or until a court decision is made, whichever is longer. The FDA may still take action for other regulatory violations, such as substandard quality or safety concerns. The National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA) is disappointed with the FDA's decision, citing ongoing lack of availability, but supports the transition period for compounding pharmacies.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[ncpa.org](https://www.ncpa.org/newsroom/qam/2025/02/13/fda-maintains-discretion-glp-1-compounding)

**GLP-1 Alternatives: 2 Stocks Benefiting From Weight Loss Trends**
The shortage of GLP-1 weight loss drugs has led to an opportunity for compounded GLP-1 treatments to enter the market. Hims & Hers Health has seen significant growth with the addition of compounded semaglutide GLP-1 injections, with Q3 2024 EPS of 32 cents and revenues soaring 77% year-over-year to $410.6 million. The company plans to bring generic GLP-1, liraglutide, to the market in 2025. LifeVantage Co. has taken a non-FDA route and markets its 'MindBody GLP-1 System', a dietary supplement system that claims to increase the body's natural production of the GLP-1 hormone. LifeVantage reported fiscal Q1 2025 EPS of 22 cents and revenues rose 31.26% to $67.76 million. The company has issued upside FQ2 2025 revenue guidance and plans to roll out its MindBody GLP-1 system internationally in March 2025.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 12, 2025 01:15 PM
Source:[marketbeat.com](https://www.marketbeat.com/stock-ideas/glp-1-alternatives-2-stocks-benefiting-from-weight-loss-trends/)

**Hims & Hers' off-brand weight loss drugs made a Super Bowl splash. Here's what to know**
Hims & Hers, a health and wellness company, aired a Super Bowl ad criticizing the high price tag of branded weight-loss drugs. The ad, which featured Donald Glover's 'This Is America' as its soundtrack, claimed that medications work but are priced for profits, not patients. The company's GLP-1 injections, which contain compounded or off-brand semaglutide, were briefly featured in the ad. Industry groups and lawmakers called the commercial misleading, but Hims & Hers said the backlash was an attempt to cancel an ad that directly calls out the industry's failures. The company's compounded weight-loss drugs are allowed to be sold due to Wegovy's current shortage. Hims & Hers offers the compounded semaglutide injections for $199 a month, hundreds of dollars cheaper than Ozempic and Wegovy. However, the FDA has warned about the risks of compounded formulations, which are not FDA-approved and have been linked to adverse event reports.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 10, 2025 03:55 PM
Source:[qz.com](https://qz.com/hims-hers-compounded-semaglutide-ozempic-wegovy-1851759350)

**More than half of pharmacies reported medication shortages in 2024**
According to the National Authority for Medicines and Health Products (Infarmed), 80% of the 12,436 commercialized presentations did not experience any disruptions, while 17% experienced disruptions without any impact on patients, 3% had a moderate impact, and 19 had a high impact due to a lack of substitutes in the market. The Infarmed applied measures to mitigate the impact, such as exceptional use authorization and monitoring of patient needs. In 2024, 72% of disruptions were effective, while 28% did not occur due to the measures taken. Nuno Simões, director of the Infarmed's Unit for Interinstitutional Projects and for the Health System, stated that disruptions are not unique to Portugal, but occur throughout Europe, and that there are European working groups to analyze the issue and harmonize measures to ensure greater availability of medicines at the national level and protect patients' rights. However, in more than half of the cases, this deadline was not met. The report also highlights the main causes of disruptions, including delays in manufacturing or non-compliance with contractual conditions (57.44%), increased demand (21.17%), and logistical problems (6.01%). The Infarmed is monitoring cases of prolonged shortages of certain medications, including antidiabetics, medications for hyperactivity and attention deficit, and medications for treating pancreatic insufficiency and Helicobacter pylori infections. The Infarmed expects the shortage of antidiabetics, particularly semaglutide, dulaglutide, and liraglutide, to continue throughout 2025 due to increased demand for weight loss.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 07, 2025 08:42 AM
Source:[sapo.pt](https://www.sapo.pt/noticias/atualidade/mais-de-metade-das-farmacias-reportaram_67a5c792e2651854e3074ffe)

**Inside the Compounding Boom**
Hims & Hers, an online telehealth prescription company, has purchased a 30-second ad spot during Super Bowl LIX to promote its new 'Sick of the System' commercial and its compounded GLP-1 weight-loss injections, which cost $199 per month, a fifth of the out-of-pocket cost of brand-name options. Compounded pharmacies manufacture customized medications, governed by Section 503 of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, but are not evaluated by the FDA for safety, efficacy, or quality. The FDA has raised concerns about the practices of some compounders, including replacing semaglutide with less costly, untested, and unproven salt derivatives, and warned consumers about the risk of dosing errors when using comp drugs with little to no doctor oversight. The FDA has received multiple reports of adverse events, some requiring hospitalization, due to dosing errors. The shadow prescription drug market arose from a regulatory carveout intended to address drug shortages for patients with special needs, but has become a household name.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 31, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[americanactionforum.org](https://www.americanactionforum.org/weekly-checkup/inside-the-compounding-boom/)

**The GLP-1 Saga Continues: FDA Ends the Tirzepatide Shortage: Frequently Asked Questions**
The FDA has removed tirzepatide from its list of shortage drugs, ending a regulatory back-and-forth that began in October 2024. This change affects companies making and distributing compounded copies of tirzepatide, as they can now be held in violation of the law. FDA will abstain from taking action against compound pharmacies and outsourcing facilities that discontinue making and distributing compounded tirzepatide by February 18, 2025, or March 19, 2025, respectively. However, Lilly can still sue these companies under the Lanham Act for violating its tirzepatide patent. Patients who have been prescribed compounded tirzepatide should be advised of the impending discontinuation to ensure a smooth transition. Other GLP-1 drugs, such as semaglutide, dulaglutide, and liraglutide, remain on the shortage list, and compounding pharmacies and outsourcing facilities can still make and dispense compounded copies of these drugs. However, FDA can remove these drugs from the shortage list without notice to stakeholders, so companies must be prepared to adapt.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 27, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[jdsupra.com](https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/the-glp-1-saga-continues-fda-ends-the-6020372/)

**Novo Nordisk Faces Challenge in Brazil Due to High Demand for Ozempic**
The Danish pharmaceutical company Novo Nordisk is facing a challenge in its operation in Brazil due to a higher-than-expected demand for its Ozempic medication, leading to a shortage in pharmacies across the country. The company has announced that there will be intermittent availability of the medication until June 2025. 'As a responsible supplier and always concerned with the health and safety of its patients, Novo Nordisk communicates that there will be intermittent availability of Ozempic (semaglutide 1mg) throughout the first half of 2025, due to demand higher than expected', the company stated in a note to Bloomberg Línea. The shortage is not due to quality or regulatory issues with the product, but rather due to the complexity of the distribution chain. The company expects the stock to be restored gradually, but not immediately. The availability of Wegovy and Rybelsus, other medications from the company with semaglutide as the active principle, remains unchanged. The company has also emphasized the importance for patients to follow medical prescriptions and not to use medications off-label.
Original language: pt
Publish date: January 24, 2025 11:23 PM
Source:[bloomberglinea.com.br](https://www.bloomberglinea.com.br/saude/falta-ozempic-em-farmacias-brasileiras-novo-nordisk-avisa-ficara-assim-ate-junho/)

**It's about to get a lot harder to buy knock-off Ozempic**
The FDA has removed tirzepatide from its shortage list, which will make compounded versions of the weight-loss drug no longer widely available. This change will affect patients like Jessica DeBenedetto, who has been taking compounded tirzepatide and is now devastated that this option is going away. Her doctor will switch her to compounded semaglutide, but this is only a temporary fix. The FDA is expected to eventually end the shortage designation for semaglutide as well, and compounders will have to stop making it. The transition period will not be seamless, and many patients will be left without access to these life-changing medications. The bigger picture is that there's a lot of money on the line when it comes to GLP-1s, and the parties involved know it. Compounders have found a big revenue stream they don't want to easily give up, while Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk have market exclusivity and want to make as much money as they can before it runs out. 'You're going to have a lot of very disappointed people,' said Melanie Jay, the director of the NYU Langone Comprehensive Program on Obesity. 'It's always about money,' said Jessica DeBenedetto. 'Everything's always about money, and it sucks.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2025 09:10 AM
Source:[Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/fda-compounded-tirzepatide-semaglutide-shortage-ozempic-2025-1)

**New Year, new quest to lose weight and achieve optimal health**
According to Statista, 23% of people resolve to 'live healthier' and 20% aim to 'lose weight' after overindulging during the holidays. The US weight loss market reached $89.9 billion in 2023 and is expected to grow 4.3% to $93.8 billion in 2024. Denisse Colindres, senior manager of nutrition communication at BENEO, suggests setting small, realistic goals for sustainable weight loss. She recommends focusing on progress, not perfection, and incorporating nutrient-dense foods, movement, and mindfulness. The market for prescription weight loss drugs has more than doubled in 2023, with semaglutide injections experiencing shortages and high costs. However, these medications have potential side effects, and consumers are turning to dairy and diet products for healthier alternatives. A global survey shows that two-thirds of consumers are interested in ingredients that provide protective or preventative health benefits. Dairy brands are offering tailored solutions, such as protein-rich products and reduced-sugar options, to support consumers on weight management journeys.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 20, 2025 05:00 AM
Source:[dairyfoods.com](https://www.dairyfoods.com/articles/97897-new-year-new-quest-to-lose-weight-and-achieve-optimal-health)

**Infarmed Launches Investigation into Antidiabetic Medication Shortage**
The National Authority for Medicines and Health Products (Infarmed) has initiated a 'lengthy process of audits and inspections' across the entire medication circuit, including manufacturers, distributors, pharmacies, and the healthcare system. According to a statement, this move comes after analyzing the available data on medication usage at the end of 2024, which revealed a global shortage of antidiabetic medications, specifically GLP-1 receptor agonists (Semaglutide, Dulaglutide, Liraglutide, and Exenatide). Infarmed stated that these actions began in January of this year. 'Given the analysis of the available data on medication usage at the end of 2024, the INFARMED triggered a lengthy process of audits and inspections across the entire medication circuit, from the manufacturer and holder of the market introduction authorization to distributors, pharmacies, and the healthcare system. These actions began in the current month of January,' the statement reads.
Original language: pt
Publish date: January 17, 2025 04:21 PM
Source:[sapo.pt](https://24.sapo.pt/atualidade/artigos/antidiabeticos-infarmed-desencadeia-processo-alargado-de-auditorias-e-inspecoes-a-todo-o-circuito-do-medicamento)

**Ozempic Shortage Hits Spain: A Complex Issue with Multiple Causes**
There is a shortage of the medication Ozempic, which is used to treat diabetes and obesity, in pharmacies across Spain. According to farmacéuticos, only one in five diabetics can access the medication, which has a high demand due to its effectiveness in weight loss. The shortage is attributed to various factors, including difficulties in acquiring raw materials, manufacturing problems, and a regulated pricing system that is different from other EU countries. The Agencia Española de Medicamentos has issued a warning to doctors and pharmacists to reinforce control over the prescription and dispensation of semaglutida-containing medications. Verónica Sempere, tesorera del Colegio Oficial de Farmacéuticos, assures that there is a solution for patients and that no one will be left without treatment, as there are alternative formulations available. However, the Agencia del Medicamento has not yet communicated when the supply of Ozempic will be restored. In a positive note, the shortage of Concerta, a medication used to treat ADHD, has been resolved, and new units of metilfenidato will be available in pharmacies starting in January 2025. Additionally, there are problems with the supply of Amoxicilina, an antibiotic used to combat respiratory infections, and other medications, including those used to treat cancer.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 06, 2025 04:58 PM
Source:[informacion.es](https://www.informacion.es/alicante/2025/01/06/problemas-diabeticos-medicamento-demandado-alicante-113162501.html)

**Ozempic Shortage: A Global Problem with No Easy Solution**
The semaglutide-based medication Ozempic has been widely used for weight loss, but its availability has been limited due to high demand. In Spain, the AEMPS has warned of its sale without a prescription and has implemented measures to address the shortage. However, the problem is not unique to Spain, as many European countries are experiencing similar issues. In Greece, for example, the medication is being prescribed by doctors with non-related specialties, leading to concerns about its misuse. The Greek National Health Service has issued 28 fines and penalties totaling €50,000. Patients from Bulgaria, Serbia, Romania, Italy, and Turkey are also traveling to Greece to purchase Ozempic due to its lower price. Dr. Rayna Stoyanova, an endocrinologist, warns that Ozempic should not be used for weight loss outside of medical indication. In France, Ozempic is only prescribed for type 2 diabetes, and its distribution has been suspended in some cases. The Czech Republic has also restricted its use to diabetic patients and prohibited its export. However, the measures have been criticized, and the medication has become available again in 2024. In Spain, the General Council of Pharmacists has stated that they have no knowledge of citizens traveling to neighboring countries to purchase the medication. They also emphasize that the availability of the medication is not guaranteed, even with a Spanish prescription.
Original language: es
Publish date: December 30, 2024 04:04 AM
Source:[Alimente](https://www.alimente.elconfidencial.com/bienestar/2024-12-30/ozempic-turismo-farmacias-medicamento_4031642/)

**Diabetics face medicine shortage as slimming craze thins supply of Ozempic**
A global craze for Ozempic as a weight-loss solution has led to a shortage in Malaysia, with pharmacies experiencing a surge in demand for the diabetes medication. According to Amrahi Buang, president of the Malaysian Pharmacists Society, the shortage is due to increased demand from non-diabetic individuals for its weight loss effects. Amrahi warned against using drugs for unapproved purposes without medical supervision, emphasizing that potential side effects of Ozempic include hypoglycemia or low blood sugar, which could be life-threatening. Dr. Wong Teck Wee, a consultant interventional cardiologist, highlighted the immediate side effects of Ozempic, citing a 2021 New England Journal of Medicine study, which found that between 44% and 47% of participants taking semaglutide for weight loss experienced nausea, while 30% to 35% reported having diarrhoea. Dr. Wong also noted anecdotal reports of psychological effects such as mood changes, anxiety and stress. He emphasized that rare but serious side effects, such as acute pancreatitis, have also been reported, although causality has not been definitively established. Dr. Lim Chong Wei, an endocrinology, diabetes and internal medicine specialist, clarified that semaglutide was originally approved as a weekly injection for Type 2 diabetes, typically combined with the right diet and exercise. He emphasized that semaglutide should be used alongside lifestyle and dietary changes, where these modifications alone often lead to minimal weight loss.

This can cause increased demand, paralleling the consumption behaviors visible in countries with significant K-pop influence, thus increasing the probability of shortages.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Supply Chain Dependencies
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Korea, being a major hub for both technology and pharmaceutical innovations, sometimes gets affected by supply chain issues which can cascade to global markets, including the availability of generic or branded medications like semaglutide. Geopolitical factors in neighboring regions could affect production or distribution logistics.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Pharmaceutical Manufacturer Capabilities
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: South Korean pharmaceutical companies are expanding capabilities to meet high demand in both local and international markets. This expansion helps buffer global supplies against shortages to some extent, thereby decreasing the likelihood of a shortage.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The continued reports of shortages of semaglutide and other GLP-1 medications across various countries, including Brazil, Spain, and Malaysia, underscore the high demand that contributes to ongoing shortages. This information is consistent with growing demand driven by weight loss trends, which aligns with previous analysis on the global demand influenced by cultural trends.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The ending of the BCG vaccine shortage in the US and efforts by pharmaceutical companies to address shortages suggest potential improvements in managing supply chain issues. The FDA's flexible approach towards compounding during drug shortages could mitigate the immediate unavailability of substitutes.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, drug shortages have occurred for various reasons, including manufacturing delays, supply chain disruptions, and increased demand. Examining FDA reports from the past few years, particularly for injectable drugs, suggests an annual chance of around 10% for notable shortages specific to high-demand medications. Given that semaglutide is a relatively new drug with increasing popularity for weight management and diabetes control, the base probability of a shortage is set at 10%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Increased Demand
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Semaglutide has become highly popular due to its efficacy in treating obesity and diabetes, leading to higher demand. This increased demand can strain the supply chain, particularly if production cannot be scaled rapidly. Thus, demand pushes the likelihood of a shortage upward.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Manufacturing Complexity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The production of semaglutide involves complex biochemical processes that require precision and highly controlled environments. These factors increase the risk of production delays or disruptions, which can contribute to potential shortages.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Supply Chain Resilience
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Improvements in supply chain practices since the COVID-19 pandemic have enhanced the resilience and responsiveness of pharmaceutical supply chains. Many manufacturers have increased inventory levels and diversified supply bases, which can mitigate some of the risks of shortages.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Regulatory Scrutiny and Compliance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Tight FDA regulations and inspections can occasionally lead to temporary shutdowns if compliance issues are identified, potentially contributing to shortages. However, manufacturers of high-demand drugs often prioritize resolving such issues quickly.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The demand for GLP-1 receptor agonists like semaglutide has been surging, as seen in multiple reports of ongoing shortages due to its popularity for weight loss. The increased demand relative to supply capabilities has been corroborated by sources indicating significant shortages globally, which aligns with the initial analysis of heightened demand leading to supply issues. Furthermore, Hims & Hers' move to offer compounded semaglutide highlights the inadequacy of current production levels to meet demand, reinforcing the likelihood of shortage.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: While demand pressures are evident, other factors such as the recent resolution of the tirzepatide shortage and ongoing efforts to ramp up production capacity by pharmaceutical companies indicate a proactive response to potential shortages. Additionally, there is an indication of regulatory adaptability to approve compounded treatments in light of shortages, which might somewhat ease pressure on supply.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To establish the initial probability, I considered historical data on drug shortages reported by the FDA. Over the past decade, approximately 5% of approved drug products have experienced significant shortages at any given time. Semaglutide, specifically, is a relatively new drug in high demand due to its use in weight management and diabetes treatment. Past shortages, particularly for high-demand diabetes medications, have at times been attributed to supply chain issues, increased demand, and manufacturing disruptions, providing a relevant context for this forecast. Therefore, starting with a base rate probability of 5% seems reasonable.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Increased Demand
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Since its approval, semaglutide has gained significant attention due to its effectiveness in weight management and glycemic control, leading to a surge in demand. Such heightened demand can outpace supply capabilities, increasing the likelihood of a shortage.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Supply Chain Disruptions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Global supply chains have experienced considerable disruptions post-pandemic, affecting the pharmaceutical industry. Although efforts have been made to stabilize these supply chains, ongoing geopolitical tensions and logistical challenges still pose risks, potentially exacerbating shortages for pharmaceuticals including semaglutide.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Producer Capacity Increases
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Drug manufacturers have recognized the high demand for semaglutide and have reportedly increased production capacities. This proactive measure to scale production reduces the likelihood of shortages despite rising demand.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several articles indicate ongoing shortages of semaglutide and similar medications globally, due to high demand for off-label weight loss use. The reports show that shortages are widespread and persistent due to demand surges, as noted in the article by Pharmacy Times and MarketBeat referencing semaglutide in compounded forms due to shortages of branded versions.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: One point challenging the potential for a shortage might be the proactive measures seen in the production of other pharmaceuticals, such as the resolution of the BCG shortage through innovation and collaboration, which could imply similar potential for addressing semaglutide shortages.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To forecast the probability of semaglutide injections being in shortage according to the FDA on April 1, 2025, I start with base rates of similar pharmaceutical shortages. Historically, the FDA reports shortages in the U.S. have fluctuated. For instance, in 2019, there were approximately 282 active drug shortages. While this base rate provides a general idea of drug shortages, semaglutide is a specific drug related to high-demand conditions such as diabetes and weight management where demand can outstrip supply.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Increased demand due to obesity and diabetes rates
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given the rising rates of obesity and diabetes, the demand for semaglutide injections has increased. This factor suggests there is a higher likelihood that demand may lead to shortages, unless supply has been correspondingly increased.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Manufacturing capacity and supply chain
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The ability of manufacturers to meet high demand is critical in maintaining supply. If there are any disruptions or limitations in manufacturing capacity or in the supply chain (e.g., raw material shortages, geopolitical issues affecting production sites), the probability of a shortage increases.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Regulatory approvals and competition
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The presence of alternative drugs and recent approvals of other diabetes or weight management drugs could alleviate pressure on semaglutide supply. The dynamic introduction of competitor products may decrease demand pressure solely on semaglutide.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous shortages and FDA warnings
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If there have been recent shortages or supply warnings from the FDA regarding semaglutide in the past year, it suggests a pattern that could increase the likelihood of future shortages.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple news articles highlight ongoing global shortages of semaglutide (Ozempic) due to increased demand linked to weight loss trends. Articles specifically mention shortages in various countries, including Spain and Brazil. A report from Infarmed in Portugal anticipates continued shortages of semaglutide throughout 2025.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: There are reports of efforts to address and manage drug shortages in other pharmaceutical sectors, such as the end of the BCG vaccine shortage in the United States, demonstrating that shortages can be resolved with concerted efforts.
